cite: The classic treatment of coercion and state power comes from Max Weber, “Politics as a Vocation,” in From Max Weber: Essays in Sociology, ed. H. H. Gerth and C. Wright Mills (New York: Oxford University Press, 1946), 78. For conquest in the western U.S., see Patricia Nelson Limerick, The Legacy of Conquest: The Unbroken Past of the American West (W.W. Norton & Co., 1987), 45–46, 91–96; Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz, An Indigenous Peoples’ History of the United States (Beacon Press, 2014), 133-161; Jeffrey Ostler, The Plains Sioux and U.S. Colonialism from Lewis and Clark to Wounded Knee (Cambridge University Press, 2004), 13-106.

Many thanks to Claudio Saunt for providing data for native land, cessions, and government reservations. Claudio Saunt et al., "The Invasion of America: How the United States Took Over an Eighth of the World," eHistory.org, http://invasionofamerica.ehistory.org/. I have made some minor adjustments to specific shapefiles.

The western U.S. has been shaped by a process of settler colonialism: the elimination or removal of indigenous people and their replacement by a colonizing population. Settler colonialism is a state-backed project, and the U.S. Post was one channel through which the U.S. government supported it. For the theoretical foundations of settler colonialism, see Patrick Wolfe, “Settler Colonialism and the Elimination of the Native,” Journal of Genocide Research 8, no. 4 (2006): 387–409; Lorenzo Veracini, “‘Settler Colonialism’: Career of a Concept,” The Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History 41, no. 2 (2013): 313–333. For settler colonialism in the context of the U.S. West, see Margaret D. Jacobs, White Mother to a Dark Race: Settler Colonialism, Maternalism, and the Removal of Indigenous Children in the American West and Australia, 1880-1940 (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 2009), 1-86.

Although I first came across Richard Helbock’s work after he had already passed away in 2011, I am indebted to his lifetime of work and passion for philately. I purchased a CD-ROM of his dataset that was still available for sale online, containing digitized versions of eight volumes that Helbock had published on the post offices in different regions of the country. Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume I – The West (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 1998); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume II – The Great Plains (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 1998); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume III – The Upper Midwest (Lake Oswego, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2001); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume IV – The Northeast (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2001); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume V – The Ohio Valley (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2002); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume VI – The Mid Atlantic (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2004); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume VII – The Lower Mississippi Valley (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2005); Richard W. Helbock, United States Post Offices Volume VIII – The Southeast (Scappoose, Oregon: La Posta Publications, 2007).

Data for other government institutions comes from two sources: The Official Register of the United States, 1877 (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1877) and Benjamin Brands, “Mapping the Army: Professionalization and 19th Century Army Posts,” Benjamin Brands Personal Website, December 11, 2014, http://benjamindbrands.net/uncategorized/mapping-the-army-professionalization-and-19th-century-army-posts-final-project-blog/. Many thanks to Benjamin Brands for providing me with data for the U.S. Army.

Royce, Indian Land Cessions in the United States, vol. 2, Eighteenth Annual Report of the Bureau of American Ethnology (Washington, D.C.: U.S. Government Printing Office, 1899), 922-923, https://archive.org/stream/annualreportofbu218smit#page/922/mode/2up. For a discusison of the larger ethical and political dimensions of this kind of data, see Catherine D’Ignazio and Lauren Klein, Data Feminism (MIT Press, Forthcoming).

Post offices from Helbock's dataset were assigned coordinates by attempting to "fuzzy match" their name, county, and state to entities in the Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) database. Roughly 30% of western post offices could not be located through this process.

Anne F. Hyde, Empires, Nations, and Families: A History of the North American West, 1800-1860 (Lincoln, NE: University of Nebraska Press, 2011), 409; Steven Hahn, A Nation Without Borders: The United States and Its World in an Age of Civil Wars, 1830-1910 (New York: Viking, 2016), 141–46.

For the challenges that the western U.S. posed for national expansion, see Susan Schulten, “The Civil War and the Origins of the Colorado Territory,” Western Historical Quarterly 44, no. 1 (2013): 23–26; Brian Delay, “Independent Indians and the U.S.-Mexican War,” The American Historical Review 112, no. 1 (February 1, 2007): 35–68; Rachel St. John, “Contingent Continent: Spatial and Geographic Arguments in the Shaping of the Nineteenth-Century United States,” Pacific Historical Review 86, no. 1 (February 1, 2017): 18–49.

For the role of the U.S. Post in Gold Rush California, see David M. Henkin, The Postal Age: The Emergence of Modern Communications in Nineteenth-Century America (University Of Chicago Press, 2006), 119-147. For the campaigns of extermination waged against California's native inhabitants, see Benjamin Madley, An American Genocide: The United States and the California Indian Catastrophe, 1846-1873 (New Haven, CT: Yale University Press, 2016).

For the ongoing power of native groups during this era, see Pekka Hämäläinen, “Reconstructing the Great Plains: The Long Struggle for Sovereignty and Dominance in the Heart of the Continent,” The Journal of the Civil War Era 6, no. 4 (November 3, 2016): 481–509, https://doi.org/10.1353/cwe.2016.0070

Historians who have emphasized the instability of the western economy include Patricia Nelson Limerick, The Legacy of Conquest: The Unbroken Past of the American West (W.W. Norton & Co., 1987), 147, 248; Richard White, “It’s Your Misfortune and None of My Own”: A New History of the American West (University of Oklahoma Press, 1991), 285; Historian James Belich argues that the “settler revolution” of the Anglo world was fueled by a similarly cyclical pattern of boom, bust, and “export rescue” from a settler colony’s metropole. James Belich, Replenishing the Earth: The Settler Revolution and the Rise of the Anglo-World, 1783-1939 (Oxford University Press, 2009), 5–8, 83–95, 182–209.
